snippet.textDisplay: 10:19 hi brad. i think the reason a lot of black women think u don’t love yourself when u relax ur hair is not just cuz they care and what the best for ur hair but it’s also because as black people historically we’ve been told our hair, our skin, our black features are ugly so for as long as perm has existed, black people have used it because of forced assimilation into a white culture and society. the natural hair movement was a way for all black people to love the hair that grows from their scalp and was an act of rebellion against the white norms that were placed on the beauty industry
snippet.textOriginal: 10:19 hi brad. i think the reason a lot of black women think u don’t love yourself when u relax ur hair is not just cuz they care and what the best for ur hair but it’s also because as black people historically we’ve been told our hair, our skin, our black features are ugly so for as long as perm has existed, black people have used it because of forced assimilation into a white culture and society. the natural hair movement was a way for all black people to love the hair that grows from their scalp and was an act of rebellion against the white norms that were placed on the beauty industry

snippet.textDisplay: Perming i personally feel makes your hair look stringy , lifeless and thin. I wish black woman would stop being lazy it when it comes to your locs. Find styles for mid process styling. Do twist outs, wash & go, co wash instead of wash

snippet.textDisplay:
Relaxer isn't that damaging though, did throughout primary school. My hair is more straight now, having had frizzy/curly hair and I get it done in minutes compared to the hours it took. Bleaching after high school (long after I stopped relaxing) was much more damaging and causes way more breakage.

But that's my 2 cents
snippet.textOriginal:

But that's my 2 cents

snippet.textDisplay: Lol. The pink oil moisturizer is a moisturizer that is actually supposed to be used after the relaxer is washed out to moisturize ur hair. But she just used it as a protector. U can also use grease or Vaseline.
snippet.textOriginal: Lol. The pink oil moisturizer is a moisturizer that is actually supposed to be used after the relaxer is washed out to moisturize ur hair. But she just used it as a protector. U can also use grease or Vaseline.

snippet.textDisplay: It's funny how surprised u are by the relaxer... 😂😂😂😂 u can get even straighter with a silk press. I stopped relaxing my hair because i didn't know how to take care of it (even though I've been relaxed almost my whole life). I've been natural now for maybe 2 or 3 years and my hair is longer and healthier than ever.
snippet.textOriginal: It's funny how surprised u are by the relaxer... 😂😂😂😂 u can get even straighter with a silk press. I stopped relaxing my hair because i didn't know how to take care of it (even though I've been relaxed almost my whole life). I've been natural now for maybe 2 or 3 years and my hair is longer and healthier than ever.

snippet.textDisplay: Um you can have straight hair if you’re naturally curly. You can run your hands through your hair if it’s detangled.  Black hair is just hair.  The main difference is it extremely versatile, there are a large variety of textures, lengths, and thickness.  It also protects us from the elements.  It cools us from the heat and warms us in the cold. And our hair is absolutely beautiful.
snippet.textOriginal: Um you can have straight hair if you’re naturally curly. You can run your hands through your hair if it’s detangled.  Black hair is just hair.  The main difference is it extremely versatile, there are a large variety of textures, lengths, and thickness.  It also protects us from the elements.  It cools us from the heat and warms us in the cold. And our hair is absolutely beautiful.

snippet.textDisplay: Relaxers are damaging period.  You literally can’t have healthy hair with an extremely alkaline chemical on acidic hair.  The relaxers job is to break down the hair strands it continues to do so after the relaxer is rinsed off.
snippet.textOriginal: Relaxers are damaging period.  You literally can’t have healthy hair with an extremely alkaline chemical on acidic hair.  The relaxers job is to break down the hair strands it continues to do so after the relaxer is rinsed off.

I haven't had one in about half a year though and my hair's recovering because of braids and protective styles

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Brad! I know you usually focus on colour-themed videos and reacting videos but lately there has been an uproar about DevaCurl being accused of damaging peoples hair and causing hairloss and health issues! I would love an opinion from a non biased proffessional like yourself! I am a curly girl and have been so confused as to why my hair has been so dry and damaged even though ive been treating it like a queen and natural for the last 3/4 years. The damage has increased this last year just like most people have confirmed. I think a lot of curly girls would love your input from an outside perspective <3 thank you!!
snippet.textOriginal: Hey Brad! I know you usually focus on colour-themed videos and reacting videos but lately there has been an uproar about DevaCurl being accused of damaging peoples hair and causing hairloss and health issues! I would love an opinion from a non biased proffessional like yourself! I am a curly girl and have been so confused as to why my hair has been so dry and damaged even though ive been treating it like a queen and natural for the last 3/4 years. The damage has increased this last year just like most people have confirmed. I think a lot of curly girls would love your input from an outside perspective <3 thank you!!

snippet.textDisplay: So many commercials and damage done to their hair. The 1st 2 videos...nope. You were right about the damaging process especially when it came out so straight. The pink cream was a protectant to apply before the chemical. Looked like she only used it for the edges though. She shouldn't have combed it through her hair. She said she wanted a looser curl pattern. Her reaction of being happy seemed fake to me.  It was straight. Barely any texture.
snippet.textOriginal: So many commercials and damage done to their hair. The 1st 2 videos...nope. You were right about the damaging process especially when it came out so straight. The pink cream was a protectant to apply before the chemical. Looked like she only used it for the edges though. She shouldn't have combed it through her hair. She said she wanted a looser curl pattern. Her reaction of being happy seemed fake to me.  It was straight. Barely any texture.

snippet.textDisplay:
Quit piercing your beautiful lips, I caught myself going in for a kiss!
Also, loving the darker hair. You look much younger and less 90's😛
Do not relaxers use the same chemicals as a perm? I was under the assumption they were the same. Thus both are damaging as the other?
One more thing, I (caucasian,German<blonde>descent)get my hair braided a couple times a year from a predominantly African salon. In between I go to a predominantly caucasian salon for colour/cuts. My African salon takes a lot of time w each client, I never feel rushed. My caucasian salon has a rushed feeling (plus its 1 of 5 aveda salons in a city of 6 million). I can only conclude that African hairstylists understand patience because African hair just takes more care. Which I will take full advantage of 😃, I love lingering in my stylists chair 😊
snippet.textOriginal:
Quit piercing your beautiful lips, I caught myself going in for a kiss!
Also, loving the darker hair. You look much younger and less 90's😛
Do not relaxers use the same chemicals as a perm? I was under the assumption they were the same. Thus both are damaging as the other?
One more thing, I (caucasian,German<blonde>descent)get my hair braided a couple times a year from a predominantly African salon. In between I go to a predominantly caucasian salon for colour/cuts. My African salon takes a lot of time w each client, I never feel rushed. My caucasian salon has a rushed feeling (plus its 1 of 5 aveda salons in a city of 6 million). I can only conclude that African hairstylists understand patience because African hair just takes more care. Which I will take full advantage  of 😃, I love lingering in my stylists chair 😊

snippet.textDisplay: I've been natural for about 2 years. It's very thick and is definitely a handful to care for and style. But my hair is so much healthier nature and that's what it's all about for me. I didn't really know how to take care of my relaxed hair and had breakage and couldn't grow past a certain length. I support all men and women on their hair journeys. I love you Brad for doing this research and letting the world see more African American hair with understanding and not bias.
snippet.textOriginal: I've been natural for about 2 years. It's very thick and is definitely a handful to care for and style. But my hair is so much healthier nature and that's what it's all about for me. I didn't really know how to take care of my relaxed hair and had breakage and couldn't grow past a certain length. I support all men and women on their hair journeys. I love you Brad for doing this research and letting the world see more African American hair with understanding and not bias.

snippet.textDisplay: I have naturally straight hair, nearly all my life I have curled it every morning filled it full of products and sprays. Finally now I’m 30 this year, I have used a curler only once in 2 years, I accept it because I am thankful how easy it is to manage! I love curls though, I’ll always wish I had volume and curls lol.
snippet.textOriginal: I have naturally straight hair, nearly all my life I have curled it every morning filled it full of products and sprays. Finally now I’m 30 this year, I have used a curler only once in 2 years, I accept it because I am thankful how easy it is to manage! I love curls though, I’ll always wish I had volume and curls lol.

snippet.textDisplay: @BradMondo for the first video that look is totally achievable without the relaxer, it just isn’t permanent.
snippet.textOriginal: @BradMondo for the first video that look is totally achievable without the relaxer, it just isn’t permanent.

snippet.textDisplay:
The second girl made me nervous.

DO NOT wash and blow dry your hair before a relaxer. The least amount of manipulation, the better. In fact you want at least 2-3 days of low manipulation before the relaxer application.

DO NOT scratch your scalp 2-3 days before application. Tears or scratches to the scalp are the kiss of death

DO plan where/how/timing of the relaxer application before you go in. Have a full plan to achieve a consistent result for all of your hair. Key to a consistent result is knowing the various textures in your hair and which areas will require more/less time to process.

DO apply a protective barrier to your edges and ears. Vaseline will do. Best would be a protective product designed to work with the relaxer. If you use Vaseline or some other base, don’t cover areas your want to relax since the base will act as a barrier and lessen the efficacy of the relaxer

DO detangle and separate your hair into at least 4 sections to apply. Be gentle.

DO leave about 1/4 inch to the roots for the last phase of application

DO part and apply the relaxer in smaller sections (apply downward. Let the hair lay flat) and work quickly. Don’t slather it in with your hands like a moisturizer. A brush applicator is best. You can use a narrow toothed comb if you know what you’re doing. You may need to do some light combing to ensure the product is applied to tangle free hair (very important).

DO get the product applied to all of the hair before you start working the product in.

DO finish out the root application then fully work the product in again

DO pay attention to timing and monitor your hair while the relaxer is processing. You can look at your hair and see the texture change with the product in it. Stay keen to when you see you hair reaching the desired result and keep watch on the clock. This dual diligence is important. You don’t want to over process your hair.

DO thoroughly rinse out all of the product and quickly apply the neutralizer wash. If you experience a burning sensation before you achieve the desired result, rinse the product out right away (still apply the neutralizer. Always neutralize whenever you have relaxer in your hair for any length of time).

DO give the hair a good deep conditioning or an otherwise moisture restorative process.

DO keep the hair moisturized post application and styling. Oil moisturizers, sprays or some other daily moisture routine will help your hair stay healthy and avoid breakage. Try to stay away from products with drying alcohols.

DO minimize heat styling

DO have a head covering or pillow covers that are kind to the hair. Silk or satin bonnets and pillow covers

DO minimize exposure to the elements ongoing

DO have a reasonable “touch up” routine. A “touch up” is when you go in and relax new growth so that is is consistent with the rest of your already relaxed hair. This is a balance - you don’t want to wait too long or the hair will start to break due to the 2 textures. You also want to ensure you have enough new growth for a touch up and that you aren’t double processing the same hair (applying product to already relaxed hair). Only apply relaxer to the new growth. 1/4 inch or more is usually safe

DO go to a professional. DIYing this process can be dangerous. Don’t try this at home until you have some education and experience under your belt.

The second girl made me nervous.  

DO NOT wash and blow dry your hair before a relaxer.  The least amount of manipulation, the better.  In fact you want at least 2-3 days of low manipulation before the relaxer application. 

DO NOT scratch your scalp  2-3 days before application. Tears or scratches to the scalp are the kiss of death

Only apply relaxer to the new growth. 1/4 inch or more is usually safe

snippet.textDisplay: Question! I have super fine, super thin hair and for my job I’m required to wear it back constantly and through High School I wore it up in a pony or in a bun. So basically my whole life it’s been up. I didn’t start noticing it until recently but my hair line is starting to move farther and farther back and I don’t want to go bald! So I need some tips to help my hair like grow back and to prevent further thining out and balding. Help!! Thanks for any tips!
snippet.textOriginal: Question! I have super fine, super thin hair and for my job I’m required to wear it back constantly and through High School I wore it up in a pony or in a bun. So basically my whole life it’s been up. I didn’t start noticing it until recently but my hair line is starting to move farther and farther back and I don’t want to go bald! So I need some tips to help my hair like grow back and to prevent further thining out and balding. Help!! Thanks for any tips!

snippet.textDisplay: BRAD PLEASE HELP! Does purple shampoo work on hair that is NOT colored but with age my hair has gone from platinum blonde as a child and just darkened throughout the years. It's blonde but has A LOT OF RED IN IT!! I've only ever used temporary color, 29 washes and it's pretty much blonde.i have always used the same color as my own hair.  I don't have grey hair I have white hair that actually looks very shiny and pretty when i color it. But I HATE how it's turning red, just like mom and the few other blondes in my family. Please advise ✌🏼💜

snippet.textDisplay: My stylist kinda forced me to get my hair relaxed just a month after I bleached it (which I later learned that it’s a big ass No No) 3 hours later my hair started burning and clumping really bad, he said that he’ll give me a trim and that I was going to be fine (take in mind I payed 150 dollars 3000 pesos for it and they used me to practice without me consenting)  a few weeks later It got worse and I had to shave my head cause I had balls of burned hair on the back and top of my head .... It’s been a year and a half and I haven’t been able to grow it that much (not even shoulder length) cause my scalped got 2 degree burns and now with (the little amount of length I have) I have anxiety every time anyone touches my hair or when I comb it ... I have nightmares about that day.
snippet.textOriginal: My stylist kinda forced me to get my hair relaxed just a month after I bleached it (which I later learned that it’s a big ass No No) 3 hours later my hair started burning and clumping really bad, he said that he’ll give me a trim and that I was going to be fine (take in mind I payed 150 dollars 3000 pesos for it and they used me to practice without me consenting)  a few weeks later It got worse and I had to shave my head cause I had balls of burned hair on the back and top of my head .... It’s been a year and a half and I haven’t been able to grow it that much (not even shoulder length) cause my scalped got 2 degree burns and now with (the little amount of length I have) I have anxiety every time anyone touches my hair or when I comb it ... snippet.textDisplay: Growing up I always had a relaxer since I was a kid (just for me lol). I did not have a choice in what my mom did to my hair. When I hit college that’s when I learned about relaxers and the harmful stuff so I asked my mom if she can chop off all my relaxed hair and she did at that time I was doing my own hair anyways. Fast forward to a few years later my hair was shoulder length and CURLY I had no idea I had very curly hair! And I love it till this day! I also have fine hair so it straightens pretty easy but I wish my mom knew better back then. Definitely not relaxing my kids’ hair!
snippet.textOriginal: Growing up I always had a relaxer since I was a kid (just for me lol). I did not have a choice in what my mom did to my hair. When I hit college that’s when I learned about relaxers and the harmful stuff so I asked my mom if she can chop off all my relaxed hair and she did at that time I was doing my own hair anyways. Fast forward to a few years later my hair was shoulder length and CURLY I had no idea I had very curly hair! And I love it till this day! I also have fine hair so it straightens pretty easy but I wish my mom knew better back then. Definitely not relaxing my kids’ hair!

snippet.textDisplay: I love that you don't judge our hair care methods, thank you. I did the big chop to natural 10 months ago. One thing i forgot is my hirsutism so my now shoulder length hair (stretched) takes 2 hours to style and I am now suffering from tendonitis. I am now going to wig it for most of the time and save my real hair for special occasions.
snippet.textOriginal: I love that you don't judge our hair care methods, thank you. I did the big chop to natural 10 months ago. snippet.textDisplay: Can you relax your hair into less-curly hair? Like curls you would get with a curling iron for example? Because you said it stays in the position you put it in, and that's also how perms work, but can you do a 2-in1 ? Going from say 4C to 3A or 3B? It's still a lot more maintenance than straight hair but for people with the time and patience it could be super cool I guess
